questions.text: A molecular biology research team is working with E. coli DNA polymerase I and is particularly interested in a fragment of this enzyme known as the Klenow fragment. This fragment is often used in various DNA manipulation techniques due to its enzymatic properties. The team wants to clarify which activity is missing in the Klenow fragment when compared to the full DNA polymerase I enzyme. Which of the following activities is the Klenow fragment known to lack?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) 5’-3’ exonuclease

 

Option A:

 

  • In bacteria there are 5 polymerases. Arthur Kornberg (Nobel prize, 1959) isolated the DNA polymerase I (Kornberg’s enzyme) from Escherichia coli.

  • It is a repair enzyme. It has both 3′ to 5′ and 5′ to 3′ exonuclease activities.

  • When 5′ to 3′ exonuclease domain is removed, the remaining fragment retains the polymerization and proofreading activities; it is then called the Klenow fragment.

  • It is widely used in recombinant DNA technology.

 

Explanation:

 

Option B: 3’-5’ exonuclease - The Klenow fragment retains this proofreading activity, which allows the correction of errors by removing mismatched nucleotides from the 3' end of the growing DNA strand.

 

Option C: 5’-3’ DNA polymerase - The Klenow fragment also retains this essential polymerase activity, enabling it to synthesize DNA in the 5’-3’ direction by adding nucleotides to the 3' end of a DNA strand.

 

Option D: 3’-5’ DNA polymerase - This is an incorrect designation because DNA polymerase activity occurs in the 5’-3’ direction, not the 3’-5’ direction. Therefore, neither the full DNA polymerase I enzyme nor the Klenow fragment has 3’-5’ polymerase activity.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The Klenow fragment lacks the 5’-3’ exonuclease activity, which is one of the three activities possessed by the full DNA polymerase I enzyme. This activity is important for the removal of RNA primers during DNA replication and repair in the full enzyme.

 

Ref: DM Vasudevan, Textbook 7th e: pg 580.
